RT @calonghurst: Incidence of new onset type 1 diabetes increased 57% among San Diego children in the first year of the pandemic! üìà

Data f‚Ä¶

Tragically, we've all become numb to Covid's death toll. Sometimes it takes a tangible comparison to shake us out of complacency. 
I had such a moment today, when Covid deaths in the U.S. hit 875,000. That, as it happens, is the population of my city, San Francisco. Staggering. https://t.co/WjGNyy5fUE

‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs an actual risk for a Covid booster administered every 6 months or so. https://t.co/ir7NWkzgxv To me, the epidemiological data showing fewer cases & fewer severe cases would outweigh this theoretical concern. (18/25)

And, since it‚Äôs Covid, it‚Äôs not just about the individual (unlike if we were considering NNT for Lipitor in preventing MI's). Preventing infection (Israel cited a 2-fold drop in risk for symptomatic Covid) benefits the individual AND the community, by lowering spread. (16/25)

But vaccines are a bit different than cholesterol meds or chemo. First, they're incredibly safe. 2nd, they‚Äôre extremely cheap (free in fact). 3rd, the benefit is not just about preventing death, but also preventing hospitalizations, & likely lowering risk of Long Covid. (15/25)

The NNT answers this question: how many people need to get the intervention (here, a 2nd booster) to prevent the outcome of interest (here, death from Covid). We‚Äôll use this calculator https://t.co/ORjwuExroB to estimate the NNT for an intervention that reduces the‚Ä¶ (13/25)

‚Ä¶would improve them, to 1-in-2250 (0.044%). Is it worth getting the shot? 
To figure that out, let‚Äôs return to a concept I introduced when I discussed whether to treat my son‚Äôs Covid: the Number Needed to Treat (NNT). https://t.co/EU772ZKNxb (12/25)

‚Ä¶100-fold compared to an unvaxxed person (same Fig, for emphasis). 
Let‚Äôs consider a 65-year-old man w/ no additn'l risk factor. Using UK calculator https://t.co/GzN6Meygb6 (incl. vax Y/N, but built pre-Omicron), risk of 65 yo dying after case of Covid was 1-in-442 (0.2%).(7/25) https://t.co/UhlAp6llyS

‚Ä¶Covid was, say, one-in-ten (IT'S NOT!), the decision would be a no-brainer: one-in-10 vs. one-in-30 is a big, clinically meaningful, difference. 
But the population at issue here is people who‚Äôve already gotten 3 shots ‚Äì they‚Äôve lowered their risk of severe infection‚Ä¶ (6/25)

Let‚Äôs start with Q2 first. As with many Covid risk-benefit calculations, it is massively complicated & fairly nuanced. A 3-fold drop sounds like a lot, & so the decision to take a remarkably safe booster may feel like a slam dunk. And if your risk of dying from a case of‚Ä¶(5/25)

When cases were skyrocketing (in early Jan), the 7-day average of cases UNDERestimated what was happening "right now." Conversely, a 7-d avg OVERestimates cases when they're...(1/7)üßµ

RT @gregggonsalves: A cri de coeur from @meganranney: "Two years ago, I hoped the pandemic would help us marshal resources and political wi‚Ä¶

Covid-19 accelerated the digital transformation of healthcare, and gave us a taste of the potential (particularly in telemedicine & #dataviz). Terrific @theNAMedicine report explores lessons learned & the enormous work that remains. https://t.co/V3YqaSqVK1 #TransformingHealth

I feel for you. Vaccines do have partial efficacy for some. And Paxlovid is a huge deal; it works independent of the immune system. Assuming its 90% efficacy against severe cases holds up, it should bring the risk down to a level where Covid doesn't feel like a constant threat. https://t.co/MiCACPv5np

‚Ä¶ ticking through a Covid risk algorithm several times a day is attractive.
After living w/ the anxiety of Covid for so long, this transition is as tricky as the one we made in March 2020. We‚Äôll all need to sort it out at our own pace ‚Äì¬†let's be patient with one another.(25/end)

‚Ä¶I plan to act, well, normal. I‚Äôll accept the possibility that I‚Äôll get Omicron, reassured by the high likelihood that it‚Äôll be a mild case, that I‚Äôll be able to diagnose it quickly & isolate, & that chances of Long Covid are very low in fully vaxxed people. Of course,...(22/25)

Some of my masking will be protection not just vs. Covid but also other respiratory bugs, incl. flu. I used to get a nasty URI every winter, which triggered my asthma, and I haven‚Äôt had that for 2 years. If masking in high-risk places makes wheezing less likely, why not? (18/25)
